message: I'm new to this API using development and was thinking about where to get started, maybe there are some good hints / ideas (also see a blog post of mine where I talk about this and some ideas http://goo.gl/hR9nv)
curl ;)
writing unit tests for existing libraries for the API is another good method of learning
I either try to find an existing client library and tinker around with it in the Ruby (or other) console, or use something like RestClient to talk to it with only a little bit of an abstraction.
play first … test later
Play by testing... :)
Do you start by looking for frameworks / implementations of the APIs?
Consoles are good, apigee.com has a few nice consoles for popular APIs
yep, good one!
So let's say you have found an interesting API (convore, hunch, simplegeo, google apis, facebook, twitter, etc.) - where do you usually start when developing an app against it?
Do you go ahead and start coding your own implementation?
Do you test the API first using its console (if there is one)?
@kaerast Wow http://apigee.com/ looks nice for testing. Thanks, didn't know about it.

I usually use curl/restclient to play around with the API, before I try out a client library. This way I have a better understanding of what actually happens, especially when the degree of abstraction in the library is rather high.
I would start with unit tests as well.
@skohler Yes. I am aware of that. Both products are great by the way! :-)
There is also http://hurl.it/ which is similar to http://apigee.com/
@otaviofff Now that you say it - hurl was written (in part) by @leah which happens to work on/for convore. What small world we live in ;-)
http://hurl.it useful tool, since you can save settings and share
@locks haha, from the GitHub group ;)
there's also http://htty.github.com/
hurl.it is down that sucks guess time to use htty or apigee
What are @defunkt and @leah saying to hurl.it being down?

@italiano40 What? When? Why? I used it on Friday (as a starting point for API development - see blog post: goo.gl/w4Lyd) and it worked fine. One could still run an own version of it as it is open source - right?
it's down for me as well
@skohler yea it is open source and no they said nothing I know about, and it is still down
htty looks slick
hurl goes down every once in a while
it's back now
i'm not sure why it keeps dying and don't have a ton of time to devote to it =/
